addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good L.
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

21 Julie
1594
M
r
Bodley to my Lo:/
From
e Haghe.
C
o
fesseth
e recept
e
Recept of m
y
of
e 7
e 19./

page.lettertext:
fol.57r
7 Ju
l
May it please yo
r
good L. By yo
r
letter
of
e 7 w
ch
I receaved
e 19 having had full intelligence,
at her
Ma
tie
is determined, to goe forward w
t
her purpose, for
e
rescue of
Brest,
and to have
e assistance of
e
states
re-
quired thereunto, I moved them in it yesterday, and
had their answear presently, w
ch
was to this effect, That
they have signified already by their l
re
s to her Ma
tie
,
at
they will streine their abilitie to
e uttermost degree to
second her designe, and whensoever they may knowe her
finall resolution, they will presently arme their Navie.
For they thinke it very necessarie,
at they should be first
made acquainted w
t
e time to sette fourthe,
e place of
e
Rendez vous,
e numbers of her shippes, souldiers, munition,
powder, and other provisions, w
t
all
e project of
e service,
to
e end they may proceede, w
t
a sounde deliberation, and
provide themselves thereafter of every thing requisit.
That otherwise if they should presently sette forwarde, it
might befalle them at this time, as it would have done
before, upon my first proposition,
at in making speedely
towardes
Portesmouth
or
Plimmouth,
as was required
then of them, they should have made a fruitlesse voiage,
and burdened
e contrey w
t
a needelesse charge for two
or three monethes, so as nowe at this p
nt
, they should have
wanted
e meanes to yelde any succo
rs
. In w
ch
respect they
are desirous to knowe of her Ma
tie
her last determination,
w
t
every particular and necessarie circumstance, and
that then for their portion, they will alwaies be as forward
as can in reason be required. If I
had
knowen those
particular demaundes, w
ch
it seemeth by yo
r
l
re
s, her Ma
tie
proposed to their Agent
M
r
Caron
, I might better have bin
able to negotiat w
t
them. For nowe I could but deale in
certaine general termes, not knowing w
at
mater, those
demaundes might import. Heere is no reso-
lution taken, for any further imploiment of their forces
at home,
e state seeming bent, to refreshe their souldiers
for a while in their garrison townes, for w
ch
I will be earnest
fol.57v
to gette thos e of her Ma
tie
to be somwhat better fournish
ed.
They passed a promesse a great while sins to
e
Frenche K.
that after
Groeninghen
was reduced, they would spare
him 3000 footmen, and five hundred horse for the
space of 3 monethes, to be commaunded by
e
D.
of
Bourb
on
and imploied as he thought good, against
e contreis
of
Artois,
and
Hennawlt,
or any other place, to
e annoia
nce
of
e Enemie. This promesse being made, I suppose th
ey
will perfourme, if
e Duke be ready for it, and hath c
[ast]
his plotte to good effect: wherunto, as it seemeth, they
[.]
tend to knowe his answear. Their Deputies
for
Scotland,
are upon their departure, whose present at
e
Christninge is two standing cuppes of pure gold, amoun
ting
to
e value of 1200
li
ster
l
and a certaine patent fro
m
the
Provinces,
inclosed also in a boxe of gold, contain
ing
the graunt of an annual pension of 500
li
during
e li
fe
of
e yonge
Prince,
to be enjoied by himself, or bestowe
d
on any other. But this they are unwilling to have publik
ly
knowen.
Having no other mater I take my humble
leave
From
e Hage July 21 1594.
Yo
r
L. most humble at commaundem
t
Tho. Bodley.
